Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting.
Body is dark amber.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain, caramel), moderately to heavily hoppy (resin), lightly yeasty (dough), with a note of alcohol.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately acidic, heavily bitter.

Medium to full body, syrupy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic, moderately astringent.

One-dimensional resinous hop odor and a very astringent, acidic, acrid, crudely bitter mouth experience.  A silly beer.

Dark, cloudy, caramel color with good, creamy, tan head / Nose of cut pine and caramel / Medium body, fine carbonation, malty, with great, hoppy, balance and long, lightly sweet and bitter, finish / Flavors of cut pine and resin with caramel, brown sugar, and grapefruit notes / Pretty much a double ipa.  Could use a little more fruit to balance out the hoppy bitterness, but still very good.

Deep chestnut brown with fading head.  Potent slightly vanilla hopped grassy pine to smell, fairly pungent with a touch of caramel and almond.  The body is slightly viscous with a tooth coating bitteringly chocolate touch and a floral piney echo lasting well into the finish.  Seemingly rough and abrupt it mutates into a more balanced and nuanced finish highlighted by mocha figs and hay.  Easy to drink despite its rough edges.
bottle.  clear reddish bronze.  hoppy, tea smell.  flavor is mix of hops and malts.  sweet malts and biting hops.  medium body.   lots of everything.

Bottle from brewery.  Looks like a bastard in the glass.  Aroma is pine, citrus, hops, and sweet malt.  Taste is dominated by somewhat bitter hops although the bitterness if relatively restrained by Stone standards (perhaps the oak influence).  I also taste dark malt, underlying caramel, and an alcohol tinge after the finish.  Solid enough beer.

22oz bottle. Poured a deep amber color with a large sized off white head. Lacing left on the glass. Aromas of wood, citrus, some pine, and caramel. Tastes of caramel, dark fruits, citrus, and lighter wood.

Poured a very dark brown with a foamy off-white head.  Aroma is very hoppy with fruit and citrus.  Slightly oak-ey notes as well.  Taste is quite hoppy but with a good amount of sweet fruity flavors.  Finish has lots of caramel malts.  Hops are slightly floral.  A tad smokey with some oak?  Overall a very good IPA, it is very crisp and drinkable.  Not too sweet or too bitter, the balance is just right.

22oz bottle.  Dark orange-red with a small light brown head.  Pine and candied citrus hop aromatics, some underlying maltiness.  Heavy piney resinous hop character, somewhat medicinal bitterness.  Some caramel and alefruit in the finish, with a lingering grassy hop component.  Mouthfeel is a light medium, somewhat dry.

Bomber->trappist: Pours an ultra-thin, brown, quickly diminishing head atop a murky amber body.  Aroma of citrus, sugar, and candy.  Body is medium, long on the palate, starting out lightly sweet, then going moderately bitter far into the aftertaste.  This beer is not deceptive--it lets you know you are consuming a much higher ABV than usual--which hopefully the drinker will take into consideration.  Another fine brew from Stone.

Pours a dark copper color with a very dense creamy, tan head that really is rather impressive and long lasting. Aroma has a strong piny and citrus nose of Chinook as well as a mild oak and low toasted malt nose. Flavor has an awesomely strong and slightly harsh piny presence, a light toasted middle and a modest citrus ending with a light oaky kick to finish it off. Body is modest with a very, very, very creamy feeling. Overall a very tasty brew with a very bitter, slightly rough hoppiness that is kicked up a notch from the light oaky finish. The head on this beer is one of the more impressive ones I have seen in a long time as it entices you to sip, leaving a foamstash as proof you drank it.

22oz Bottle thanks to Toby. Pours out a mahogany topped with a sand head. Aroma was of tropical fruit, lots of citrus, caramel, and a touch of wood. Taste was much the same with lots of hops and thick rich malt sweetness.

22oz bottle. Pours a mostly clear, deep ruby-brown colored body with an inch thick, dense and frothy, tannish beige head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice, sticky lacing throughout. Very pretty beer. Aroma is fresh and fruity with lots of dry hops. Sweeter citrus pines and a light resin with floral oranges, pineapples, and grapefruits. A sweet caramel backing with some golden raisins, melons, and barely a hint of oak. Flavor has lots of piney, resiny, dry, sharper hops up front. Some mild oak, a fruity mixture, and a somewhat denser caramel with a light sweetness that provides just enough balance with the bigger hops. Just barely a hint of toasty cookie to the caramels. Finishes very dry, piney, and has a medium-high bitterness with a lengthy, citrusy aftertaste. Medium, dry body and a fairly lively, but soft and creamy carbonation that works really well with this. Overall, a very enjoyable beer. Tons of dry, piney hops with a nice citrusy aspect and a solid malt balance that still allows the hops to dominate. A nice blend of the bastard and double bastard.

Bomber. This beer is wonderful!!! Pours very dark amber, with very thin head, that quickly dissapates. Aroma is very citrus (grapefruit), pine/grassy, and with some light vanilla undertones. The aroma is very IPA smelling, even though it lists as a strong American ale. First sip confirms the aroma, again grapefruit, very piney/grassy, with oily mouthfeel, with a nice hoppy, bitter finish. Again, it tastes like an IPA also. This is a IPA masquerading as a American Strong Ale, and it isnÂ’t doing a very good job of it. I love IPA, the hoppiest, bitterest ones you can find. And I love this beer.

22 oz. bottle. Served at cellar temperature.  Pours a medium, short lived, light beige head, with some lacing, over a clear, copper brown (SRM 18) body.....nose is heavy grapefruit, lighter pine, bit of toffee/caramel.....taste is light toffee/caramel sweet to start, then heavy layers of resin, pine, grapefruit bitterness arrive and linger, accompanied by lighter pineapple and licorice, there is a tiny bit of vanilla....mouth feel is thick and sticky, carbonation creates a lingering foam. This is not a subtle beer. It has loads of hop aroma and bitterness with minimal hop nuance. The malts are there, but the hops cheerfully overwhelm them, as is typical in the Bastard/Basartd series. It is delicious, if you like BIG hops. BJCP 7/3/15/4/8

medium brown with huge tan head.  piney nose with sweet medium crystal malt nose, quite aromatic.  firm bitterness before the above mentioned malt, which is apparently special b before a lot of piney hops and a fair amount of residual sweetness with some alcohol adding wonderful depth before some oak notes.  a wonderful brew, if the beer would be categorized it really is close to a barleywine and an absolutely wonderful one, better than all the beers combined

22 oz bottle from Spirits Brick. Poured an overly bubbly deep red/amber body with a large dense light khaki head that left streaks of lace on my New Belgium tulip. Aroma started off nice with loads of citrus and grapefruits, wood and even vanilla, followed by some soggy bread and older dark fruits. OVerly carbonated super lively mouthfeel with some noticable alcohol and a dry finish that gives way to bitterness in the end. The flavor has some serious alcohol flavors along with super bitter citrus rinds and old dry crusty bread. This one is just super bitter and harsh and not really in a good way either. Perhaps this one will mellow with age like Ozzy Osbourne did.62201
22 oz bomber.  Deep red color with an inch of off white foam.  Very strong aroma of citrusy hops, malt, and some alcohol, can smell it from feet away.  Sweet with a very long bitter finish.

Pours a copper color with an off-white head. Aroma is of caramel malts, citrus hops, and a hint of alcohol. Flavor is bitter right away from the citrus and pine hops.  Nice caramel malt background that helps to balance this beer out.  Slight hint of alcohol warming but not too much.

22 oz bottle.  Clear reddish amber pour, thick sticky off-white head.  Nice looking beer, with good lacing.  Toffee, resinous, piney hops, fruit, caramel, floral bitterness, and hints of oak.  This is quite nice, I normally donÂ’t drink much Stone, but I might get more of this.

Pours a perfect deep copper.  Aroma is hops.  Taste is bastard all the way, but the hops bitterness in the finish is subdued somehow.  A very good beer, but I canÂ’t say I like it more than the original or the double on their own.
Pours dark amber brown  with a thick beige head. Aroma of citrus, pine and floral hops and toffee. Taste is what you would expect, strong, hoppy, malty, bitter finish.

DraftÂ… This beer rocks!Â… Clear, deep, dark ruby ale with copper highlights and a small, creamy, off-white head. Decent retention and very nice lacework. The bouquet presents pineapple, caramel, spruce and grapefruit. Medium to full-bodied with stinging carbonation. Sticky-sweet brown sugar and caramel up front, followed by medium to heavy pine and grapefruit rind bitterness. Lengthy, hearty, bittersweet finish. World class malt and hop bomb!

Large off-white head.
Dark Copper Color
Medium body and medium carbonation.
Piney nose
Dark roasty malts, pine resin bitterness, super-dry with very little sweetness.
dry bitter finish.
very nice

Jesus, you have to be a lukcy basartd to find this brew on here. Clever, and not surprisingly arrogant theme for this brew. Pours a cloudy reddish amber, with a medium-sized creamy tan head. That old familiar super-hopped red on the nose, with a bit of oak masked by a punch of piney, resinous hops and a thick layer of caramel malts. Dear God is this ever tasty. A blend of these three brews is perfect - the original AB is great, but leaves you wanting more. The double can be a bit hot, and the oaked version is simply too oaky - it covers too much of the flavor. This takes a bit of all three. Big, thick mouthfeel - slightly boozy, but not at all offensive in that respect. Tons of hops - this one finishes very dry, making you feel a bit like youÂ’ve just stuck a drop of pine sap in your mouth. Make no mistake - this is a palate bomb. And maybe itÂ’s just their claims of liquid arrogance and how weÂ’re not worthy that make us want to be okay with just how much of a tongue wrecker this brew is. If thatÂ’s the case, theyÂ’re onto something - itÂ’s working. IÂ’m a fan.

Pours deep clear mahogany into a Sam glass. Off-white head with excellent retention leaves spot lacing as it recedes to coat surface. Oak and resin aromas. Thick and well balanced with upfront oaked, followed by a double hot resin and a lasting bastard pine finish.  Nice.
Poured amber brown, piney and citrus hops, caramel malts, little roasted malts, little molasses.

Bottle thanks to 17thfloor for sharing. Pours a deep golden amber with a creamy off white head. Aroma is fantastic, very citric, super mango and tangerine and tropical fruit notes with some juicy fruit and just a bit of piney hops. Flavor is much less fruity but still there, the pine notes come out more, as the hops are more balanced with the caramel malts and other sweet candy malt notes. Aggressive hoppy finish, fairly bitter but doesnÂ’t bite too badly. Medium body and a sharper carbonation. Very nice, especially as it warms a bit.

Fairly dark orange/brown with nice 2 finger head. leaves good lacing. 
Smells of Hops, pine, citrus, orange, grapefruit hops and sweet brown sugar and caramel. nice balance.

Taste is a great mix of the hops and malts. pine, citrus hops with carmalized and sweet sugar rich Malts. some alcohol presense. again, a nice balance.  Medium plus body with mild to med carbonation, good hop bite and dry finish, sticky in the mouth and throat with a medium alcohol warmth. A nice surprise this one was! Great balance of the piney and citrus hops with the sweet caramels, sugar and malts. IÂ’ll be going back for more!

Bottle. Poured dark ruby brown color with an average frothy brown head that lasted and produced good lacing. Moderate to heavy complex toasted malt, earthy hop and wood aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy balanced bittersweet flavor with a solid bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. This is a solid complex beer.

Pours a dark amber brownish color, nose is a little weak, mild notes of citrus and floral hops, hints of candy sugar and oak. Taste is quite nice, really fruity and juicy, surprisingly easy to drink, light in body with decent residual sweetness. The oak compliments without competing. IÂ’m actually shocked that stone was able to put together two beers that are similar from the get go, and create a beer that is so unique.

growler poured a dark plumb brown in color with a thin off white head. aroma has sticky hops, pine resins, some citrus, sweetness, and a nicely malted base. mouth feel is big and chewy. flavor gets some bitterness going, pine, medium sweetness, a bit of the oak bastard, and some alcohol on the finish.

A big fan of the original bastard, this version tastes very hopped up, but also very malty, has a bit of a sweetness and bitterness to it as well, the most hopped of the bastards I have had, not getting the oak quality in it, but overall still a solid beer from Stone, and a welcome twist on an old fav.  Hints of a strong red ale as well.  Good quality ale.

Deep red pour with a light yellowish tan head. Aroma of fresh pine, caramel, citrus rind, light fruits, biscuit malt and wood. Flavors are bright and bittersweet, lots of pine a citrus bitterness with a light caramel/tropical fruit sweetness, spicy woody notes throughout. Somewhat heavy body with a creamy sort of mouth feel, carbonation is delicate but definitely present. Starts fruity and lightly sweet, dry malt and a wallop of piney bitterness mid palate and heads towards a dry/spicy/woody/long bitter finish. Overall, a very satisfying ASA and thankfully not too sweet, a nice balance of the style and probably ties with oaked AB as my favorite of the Bastards

650ml bottle from Bev4less. Pours a murky dark brown color with a medium beige head that has good retention and plenty of lacing. /the aroma is strong with that classic Stone aroma, perfume, citrus hops, leather and dark fruits. The flavor is hops forward with pine, citrus, pecans, thyme, leather, toffee and caramel. The palate is smooth, full and creamy with lively carbonation. Finishes long and biter with a bit of caramel and vanilla making a comeback. overall: A very potent ale, very tasty.

Dark amber/brown pour with gooey off white head and lace. Aroma is brown sugar,  resiny hops. Dark roasted malt with a nice resiiny bitter. Medium full bodied with good carbonation. nice growing bitter.

One of the better Stone beers I have had in a bit.  This is the longest description of a beer I have ever seen.

Pours dark copper with an off white head.  Citrus hops and caramel malt in the flavor and aroma.  Nice bitterness and a little boozy.  Pine.  Well done.
Aroma of citrus, pine hops with some fruit sweetness. Appearance is cola like with tan head. Flavor matches the nose, but with a big caramel malt backbone. Palate is creamy and lively. Very good.

Bomber.  Pours a reddish copper with a dense (yet small) head and aromas of sweet malt, fruit and tropical fruit malt.  I pick up peaches and mangoes heavily on the first sip, blending into a boozy and sharp hops finish.  Crisp pine and slightly astringent medicinal flavors in the finish.  This is a whoopass Stone (DIPA) Strong Ale.  Typical CA stuff, but very good.  Sweet, sharp and hoppy.

text: This starts wit a nice caramel aroma, with a touch of hops, vanilla, and oak.  It pours a clear ruby red, with a nice full finger of white head.  ThereÂ’s a big strong hop presence in this beer, with caramel malts balancing it out.  ThereÂ’s just a kiss of oak and vanilla there as well,  This is quite drinkable and quite a tasty beer.  About the only two things that would make this better would be a lower price point, and year round availability.

Draft: Orange peel and rosehip aroma. Ruby red, thin head, good lacing. Very potpourri like and perfumey. Rosehips, oak, and dried leaves. Alcohol is imposing. IÂ’ve never been a huge fan of Arrogant Bastard and this is all that i donÂ’t like about AB, magnified.

22 oz. bottle - Pours a clear mahogany color with a one finger thick light tan head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is floral and citrus hops.  Flavor is the same with the addition of a little more citrus flavor and some malt sweetness.  Medium to full body.  didnÂ’t get much of the Oaked Bastard.  To be honest, I was a little disappointed in the beer.  Still, a good beer worth buying, at least once.

Awesome pour with nice off white head that lasted for a long time.  Aroma is almost overpowering but delightful - taste is hoppy, spicy, then boozy but a nice smooth bourbon flavor though.  Aftertaste is long lasting and makes me crave more.  Wonderful!

Bottle pours hazy dark amber color with tan head.  Aroma is leafy, pine, bitter hops.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavors are well balanced.  Pine, resinous oil, the middle is leafy, and the finish has a slight touch of alcohol.  Its backed up with a strong malt backbone.  Very nice brew.

Bomber from ck1 - thanks bro!  Pours a lovely reddish brown with a 1 inch head.  Low carbonation.  Hello hops!  Aroma is all freshly cut grass and sweet fruit.  Taste carries the bitterness of the hops, sweetness of the malt and a faint amount of oakiness, all in a medium strength.  Great lacing.  As it warms a bit more of the oak and the alcohol comes through. A more hoppy Arrogant without the heavy malt sweetness of Double.  A terrific brew!  I will miss the Stone efforts as they leave WI. Truly we can be WORTHY!

On tap. It pours a deep red color with a nice tan head. The aroma is decidedly hop forward with lots of peach, citrus, and a bit of earthiness. The flavor is much maltier with some cherry, plum, lollipop sweetness and more big hop bitterness. Very big and a bit rough on the palate. Some oak flavors come through in the finish.

Bottle: &nbsp Dark caramel, huge ruby hue, large frothy off-white head, very nice lacing. &nbsp Looks pretty tasty. &nbsp Resiny nose, very faint aspects of pine and hops. &nbsp This is blended? &nbsp Definite resiny start, a little biting, hoppy to say the least. &nbsp Pretty simple, clean, moderate malt body. &nbsp Not as heavy as Double nor hoppy as the regular Arrogant. &nbsp Seems like a happy medium, and one that most hop heads would really like. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full. &nbsp A bit more malts and it would get into that Barley Wine territory. &nbsp Not getting much Oak out of this. &nbsp Perhaps a little bit on the exit. &nbsp Fairly clean, hop assertive, with a moderate malt base. &nbsp Straight forward, and pretty good.

bottle - Deep amber pour, lingering head, ample hop rich aroma with citrus and pine hops and a hint of oak.  The flavor is big.  ItÂ’s pretty much Arrogant Bastard with some additional intensity of flavor and a hint of oak from the Oaked Bastard.  Resinous hops and hint of oak and roast comprise a long, enjoyable finish.  Tasty!
Bomber Bottle. Wow! This is one bold Bastard! Lukcy me. Nice dark pour with a strong head. Zesty, pine oak hops raisin an more hops. Fantastic brew!

Aromas of grassy citrusy hops.  Flavors of serious hops which overwhelms any flavor from the malts.  Not that that is a bad thing as I love hoppy beer.  Finishes with a slight bitterness.  Overall a very very good beer.  Happy Anniversary Mr. Arrogant Bastard!

Bottle.  I didnÂ’t get to have this on draft, but I heard some pretty mixed things about the draft version... which almost made me not buy the bottle, but for the price I couldnÂ’t pass it up.. and IÂ’m glad that I didnÂ’t.  Pours a dirty amber caramel color with a nice frothy fizzy light tan head.  Aroma is awesome, super fresh piney hops, the dry hoping on this is spot on, bit of alcohol, hint of banana,  caramelized brown sugar, but dominated by the dry hopping, so piney.  Flavor leads with tons of dry piney sharp hops, quite an edge, then some of that mellowed oaked bastard comes in, typical arrogant charred oak/malt flavor, sweetness is kept in check, I am starting to pick up on that very light banana note now that someone mentioned it towards the finish, overall maybe my favorite of the group.  Job well done.  Nice body, not really sticky, great active fine carbonation, easy to drink.

Bottle from Total Wine. Poured a copper reddish brown with beautiful off white head. Aroma tons of fresh hops caramel and pine. Taste was extremely bitter with a hint of oak, caramel, burnt toast, and biscuits. Nice body. Overall a great beer.

I donÂ’t even feel like wasting my time with this rating...  This yearÂ’s Double Bastard I have tried on three separate occasions from three different locations and each time I find an off putting band-aid note that just kills what is one of my favorite beers.  Sure enough, I find the same notes in this blending of the Bastards.  Great idea by Stone but something is just off with the DBA.  Call it a Mulligan from an incredible brewery.

Same as the ordinary Bastard in every sense, except that the dry hopping leads to a earthy, resiny aroma.  This is in evidence in the flavor also, caramel, pine, earth, flowers.  The finish is an enormous hop bittering, hanging in there quite a bit, metal, earth, citrus.  Good beer, but you must like hops to enjoy it.

Bottle from Whole Foods, San Ramon, CA. Pours a deep, mahogany color with a decent off white head. Strong presence. Molasses, dry hops, and a hint of brown sugar in the aroma. Nice, potent taste. Strong hops. Alcohol is masked. Much like the arrogant...but more chewy and more of a personality. Great beer!

Bottle pours burnt amber with an off-white head.  Aroma shows notes of peach, pear, pine, with a sweet floral hop presence.  Flavor shows the same with additiona notes of oak and raisin.  Overall body is moderate to full with moderate sweetness and finishes moderately bitter.  Pretty well balanced.

Dark garnet brown with a huge off white froth. Huge resinous pine and spruce in the nose with backnotes of mango, mandarin orange, grapefruit, and perfume. The flavor is a massive malty hop bomb. Huge evergreen resin, grapefruit juice, and orange with grass and floral notes in the back. Caramel and bread make up a nice balancing malt profile. The palate is thick, aggressive, and rich. Medium to high carbonation with a resinous sticky finish.

Phenomenal stuff. Pours a dark copper with a sizable, frothy off-white head. Aroma is absolutely packed full of hops, with notes of pine, mango, guava, and clementine-- gorgeous smell. Flavor is much of the same, with more of the nectar fruit mixing beautifully with evergreen hop and a touch of caramel and toffee malt for balance. Palate is actually quite thin and frighteningly drinkable. Love this stuff.

I fully admit that I love the regular Arrogant Bastard Ale, but I rarely order it.  ItÂ’s always there, sitting on the shelves, in bars, in Vons, even Rite Aid.  When I do drink it iÂ’m always a little amazed that I donÂ’t buy it more.  Now, in contrast, I rarely ever see double bastard anywhere, even during the short period of time itÂ’s on the shelves.  When I do have it, again itÂ’s a treat.  I donÂ’t love it, and I actually prefer the traditional version a little more.  The marriage of these two beers works well.  ItÂ’s like a sturdier version of AB, with a small hint of oak.  It works, and itÂ’s a pretty solid beer for Stone.

Pours a light mahogany with a fair amount of lasting foam. Tastes light compared to the original or double bastards. A fair amount of hops with some oaky characteristics. Simpler than expected, but still good and brilliant with a green onion cheese.

Draft.  Clear copper body, medium beige body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, grapefruit, some alcohol, caramel.  Taste is moderately sweet, grapefruit, caramel, some alcohol.  Medium-full body, light stickiness.

Nice hoppy nose, very piney with lots of floral notes, touches of citrus, caramel malt sweetness, light oak and a hint of alcohol. Pours darker amber with a nice lasting off-white oily head. The flavor is strongly hoppy with nice fresh resinous pine bitterness, some light dry oaky notes, caramel malts, but not overly sweet and sugary. Alcohol pokes through, bright hoppy flavors linger, dry and oily. Really enjoyable stuff.

Boy, if DaSilky1 likes this beer than it must be good. Pours murky red/brown with a medium sized, offwhite head that leaves just a little bit of lace. Smells sweet and malty overall with some mellow hop notes toward the finish. Little bit of the oak sweetness as well. Tastes spicy and sweet with some sweet malts and lots of hop spice and a hint of oak sweetness as well. spicy, hop fruitiness dominates. Medium body, ok carbonation. I feel like I wasted my life attempting to read the bottle. blah blah blah
Amber pour.  Creamy head.  Hoppy, citrus aroma, crackers, stone fruit, golden raisins, booze.  Flavor is sweet and malty and nice and hoppy all wrapped up into a fun beer.  Very nice.

Tap.  Pours clear tawny with an average, creamy and frothy beige head, long retention with excellent lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toasted), heavy hops (floral, earthy, pine), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of alcohol and peaches.  Flavor is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toasted), heavy hops (floral, earthy, pine, spicy), and average esters (apple/pear) with notes of alcohol and peaches.  Full body, high warmth, low carbonation and creaminess with a dry and biting finish.

Growler DeCeiccoÂ’s food market. First I get the huge hoppy noise, but on the second sniff I get the alcohol and a pungent fruit. Really nice. I donÂ’t get a lot of oak, only as a back note and very faint. Very drinkable as most of the stone beers, but it will hit you fast. Nice really dark amber color.

Name rather too cutesy-poo.  Draught.  Poured woody brown red with medium white head.  Aroma: hop and citrus, rather more than their other basters.  Full flavour, large bodied, lots of malt, caramel and raisin with a hop edge.  Hop finish, but with some alcohol warmth,   Sip this.

text:
Stone and I have a lot in common...we are annoying, we recycle the same fucking joke over and over again, and we pretty much just plain suck.  WeÂ’re also both from san diego...well not me originally, but what the hey, its where I call home these days, so fuck it.  The beer seems to have been filtered through a solid piece of glass though the deep woody color is sort of nice looking.  The head too, stays fairly dolid..maybe a bit too wet to lace, but still a nice complimenting light tan covering to the crystal clear wood stained beer.  Nose-wise its got the classic bastard smell though tamer on the hop notes...its got that fruity essence of nectarine and pear with a caramel note here and there...nothing offensive other than it being very 
stone_esque. 
Flavorwise...this is actually a lot more refined and classy than regular arrogant bastard as well as lighter on the palate than both double bastard and arrogant bastard...I like this better than both of those others...this is what regular bastard should have been all along.  The palate does seem a bit watery though but the flavors are there and their refined enough not to come across as a sloppy slap in the face.  A drinkable beer and actually a pretty damn successful blend of beers for stone, especially with regular bastard being one of the beers...or is it the oaked one or both, I still donÂ’t understand.  I wonÂ’t be buying this again because its still steaming with stone house character, as it should since its just a blend, but I donÂ’t have too many bad things to say about it all things considered.
One of the greatest beers I have ever had the pleasure of trying. I can only hope that they will continue to brew this beer. If you havenÂ’t tried it yet, you should.

Just awesome.  Filled with that signature Stone hop profile plus the pineapple of the Double Bastard PLUS a hint of chocolate.  And by the way: it tastes great paired with chocolate.  Taste is on par with aroma with a solid bitter finish.  I am drinking this way faster than I should!  One of StoneÂ’s best showings, in my opinion.

bottle.  Pours a dark clear dark red with tall dense creamy off-white head that hold long and leaves beautiful lace.  The aroma is very fresh hops--citrus, resiny and almost minty!  Very delicious, and with a malt profile that does provide a pretty unique balance.  The flavor is the same.  Its like the other Arrogant Bastard interpretations: very hoppy, but without a specific direction.  Its citric, herbal, and resinous, but is somehow not complexly hoppy, just sort of muddled with all of these qualities at once.  Regardless, this is a damn delicious beer!  The alcohol is hidden pretty well too.  Its medium to full bodied with medium to light carbonation.  Overall: I will probably be trying this one again!

[3481-20101120] Tap. Super hoppy aroma has lots of citrus wood. Clear, dark red amber body with a long-lasting creamy off-white head and some thick lacing. Very citrus peel hops flavour has wood resin notes and an almost overwhelmingly hoppiness and long aftertaste. Bitter medium-full body. Too much at first but was nice to sample.
Overheard: "ThatÂ’s a lovely, welcoming, embracive kick in the teeth."
(@ Blue Monk, Buffalo, NY)

Bomber.  Pours a thick brown red, with a finger or so of white fluffy foam.  Aroma all sticky pine resin.  Taste is bitter hops and malt, with a smooth sweet character through the mid-palate, to a mild, creamy pine and roast nuts finish, with just a touch of caramel apples in the post palate. Excellent.  So pleased to see Stone nail one like this.

On tap at Malt and Vine. This beer was quite pungent. I didnÂ’t get a lot of the oak as others did; however, it did have a very nice pine hop aroma that was quite pungent. Also, there was a nice subtle malt sweetness coming through. A little boozy on the nose, I believe this is from the Double Bastard, considering that is the strongest. A tad thinner than the Arrogant, because of the increase in the ABV, I think this runs a little "thin". Still, this has an excellent texture. I was told this is a fairly fresh keg, so hops werenÂ’t a problem. This beer had a nice clean pine hop flavor. Nice lasting bitterness, and a slight boozy quality kicks in as well. Could do without the booze, but this is still pretty good. Not getting any oak as suggested -- maybe the hop flavor has to die down a bit before this happens. While I was trying this I was reminded of the 13th Anniversary, and then I read the description, and quite frankly, I donÂ’t think the blending of all the beers was necessary, but it surely is interesting. Pretty good, but considering IÂ’ve had all the elements that make up this beer, itÂ’s nothing ground-breaking.

Overall: A really big, fresh bitter as fukc beer.  The art of this beer is in the blending. It seems blended so well, it really takes a while to distinguish it from itÂ’s fresh component beers. 

To sum it up, if you like Arrogant Bastard Ale, Double Bastard Ale and or OAKED Arrogant Bastard, you will like this. With that said, this isnÂ’t far off the beaten path of either Arrogant or Double Bastard Ale, so know that going in.  ItÂ’s a fun idea that IÂ’d love to see more of from Stone.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2011 On tap at RnH, where "Lucky" was spelled correctly.  We were trying to figure out what it was.  We thought the lucky may have referred to a little wild yeast, but apparently not.  This appears to be a blend of Stone Bastard ales: Oaked Arrogant Bastard, Double Bastard, and plain old Arrogant Bastard.  CanÂ’t go wrong there!   Fresh, herby, sweet aroma.  Really good, full flavor - nutty and saturated.  Some light sourness and bitterness coming into play as well.  One sign of Stone greatness is when you can take a sip and say, "Ah, this is by Stone.  I canÂ’t put my finger on what it is I am tasting that is unique to Stone, but unique to Stone it is."  Later on, I did take a couple of points off when I had it from a bottle.  Then it tasted more yeasty, not as impressive as it was on draft.  And the incoherent label notes werent as much fun as they were supposed to be.
